misconceptions.name: Implemented an entirely different problem instead of the required number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the cost of a road trip (distance, MPG, fuel price) instead of implementing the required number guessing game with a random number between 1 and 100, looping guesses, and high/low feedback.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should solve a road trip cost calculation problem (distance/mpg*price) for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program must implement a number guessing game: generate a random integer between 1 and 100, repeatedly prompt the user to guess until they are correct, print "Too high" or "Too low" after wrong guesses, and report the number of guesses when the user is correct.
symptoms: Program asks for distance, miles per gallon, and price per gallon instead of a guess between 1 and 100.
No use of Random or generation of a secret number.
No loop to allow multiple guesses.
No conditional logic to output "Too high" or "Too low".
No termination condition based on a correct guess.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation or confusion of the assignment requirements; the student appears to be solving a different textbook-style problem unrelated to the specified number guessing game.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and list the exact required behaviors (random number generation, input guesses in a loop, high/low feedback, and counting guesses). Design your program structure around these requirements before writing code.
related_concepts: Program design based on a rubric
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire submission is a road trip cost calculator with no elements of a guessing game, random numbers, loops for repeated guessing, or high/low feedback, which strongly indicates the problem requirements were misunderstood.

evidence.note: The program calculates driving cost based on distance, MPG, and fuel price. It does not generate a random number, prompt for guesses, or provide high/low feedback, indicating the student implemented a different problem than the required number guessing game.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreted assignment requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for an entirely different problem ('Road Trip Cost' calculation) and failed to implement any part of the required Q2: Number Guessing Game. The solution lacks randomness, prompting the user for guesses, conditional feedback, and looping structure necessary for the game.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have answered a different question or submitted the wrong file/solution for Q2.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submission must implement a Number Guessing Game as described in Q2, including random number generation, user input loop, and high/low comparison logic.
symptoms: Class name is 'RoadTripCost'
Code prompts for distance, MPG, and fuel price inputs
Calculates cost using the formula: distance / mpg * price
No attempt to implement loops or random number generation relevant to Q2
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding or misreading the specific requirements of the Q2 prompt.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the requirements for Q2, which is the Number Guessing Game. Your resulting program must include a random number generator and an input/comparison loop.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code submitted is entirely dedicated to solving the Road Trip Cost problem, which has zero overlap with the Number Guessing Game required by Q2. This represents a complete failure to meet the assignment objective.

evidence.note: The class name indicates the code relates to a Road Trip Cost problem, not the Number Guessing Game.
The main logic calculates fuel cost, confirming that the student solved the wrong problem.

misconceptions.name: Complete misunderstanding of assignment requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a completely different problem (road trip cost calculator) instead of the number guessing game specified in Q2.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should solve a road trip cost calculation problem, not a number guessing game.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires writing a number guessing game where: (1) the computer generates a random number 1-100, (2) the user guesses repeatedly in a loop, (3) the program provides 'Too high' or 'Too low' hints, and (4) the game ends when the correct number is guessed.
symptoms: No random number generation
No loop for multiple guesses
No conditional logic for hints
Program calculates fuel costs instead of playing a guessing game
No game termination condition based on correct guess
misconceptions.root_cause: Student either submitted code from a different assignment, did not read the question carefully, or misunderstood the assignment requirements entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read Q2 carefully. The program must: (1) import java.util.Random, (2) use Random to generate a secret number 1-100, (3) use a while or do-while loop to repeatedly ask for guesses, (4) compare each guess to the secret number and print 'Too high' or 'Too low', (5) count guesses and print the final message when correct.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submission is definitively a different program. It reads distance, MPG, and price to calculate fuel costs—none of which are mentioned in Q2. The problem statement and sample run are unambiguous about requirements.

evidence.note: The entire program solves a different problem. Q2 requires a number guessing game with random number generation, loop-based guessing, and 'Too high'/'Too low' feedback. This code calculates road trip costs instead.

evidence.snippet: Write a program where the computer picks a random number between 1 and 100. The user guesses until they get it correct. After each wrong guess, the program tells the user whether their guess was "Too high" or "Too low".
evidence.note: The problem statement clearly specifies a number guessing game, not a cost calculation. Student's submission does not address this requirement at all.

misconceptions.name: Implemented road trip cost calculator instead of number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a program to compute the cost of a road trip using distance, MPG, and fuel price instead of implementing the required number guessing game with a random number between 1 and 100 and repeated guesses.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the task is to calculate the cost of driving a certain distance given miles per gallon and fuel price, rather than to create a number guessing game.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should generate a random integer between 1 and 100 using Random.nextInt(100) + 1, then repeatedly prompt the user to guess the number until they are correct. After each incorrect guess, it should print either "Too high!" or "Too low!", and when the correct number is guessed, it should report how many guesses were taken.
symptoms: Program prompts for driving distance, miles per gallon, and price per gallon instead of asking for a guessed number.
No use of the Random class or any random number generation.
No loop structure to allow multiple guesses.
No conditional logic that prints "Too high" or "Too low" based on a comparison with a secret number.
Final output is the monetary cost of driving, not feedback about a correct guess or number of guesses.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different assignment problems or not carefully reading and translating the problem requirements into a program design.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and design the program around the described game: generate a random number in [1,100], use a loop to repeatedly read guesses, use if/else to compare each guess to the secret number and print "Too high" or "Too low", and count guesses until the correct one is entered.
related_concepts: Mapping textual descriptions to code structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is focused on road trip cost computation with no elements related to randomness, guessing, or feedback messages; this strongly indicates the student implemented a different problem than the one assigned.

evidence.note: Code implements a road trip cost calculator, with prompts and calculations unrelated to a random number guessing game; there is no Random usage, guessing loop, or "Too high"/"Too low" logic.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Problem Submission
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for an entirely different problem (Road Trip Cost Calculator) instead of the assigned Number Guessing Game
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either misread the assignment or submitted code from a different problem without realizing the mismatch
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Read and understand the full assignment requirements before writing code. The task requires: (1) Random number generation between 1-100, (2) A while/do-while loop for repeated guessing, (3) Conditional logic for 'Too high'/'Too low' feedback, and (4) Proper termination when the correct number is guessed
symptoms: Program reads distance, mpg, and price instead of user guesses
Program performs a cost calculation instead of number comparison
No random number generation
No loop for multiple attempts
No guessing game logic whatsoever
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misalignment between assignment requirements and submission content—either accidental submission of wrong code or failure to read the assignment specification
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read Q2 requirements. Start fresh with a new program that: (1) uses Random to generate a number 1-100, (2) uses a while loop to repeatedly ask for guesses, (3) compares the guess to the secret number with if-statements, and (4) tracks guess count
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty—the submitted code implements a completely different program with zero alignment to the Number Guessing Game specification

evidence.note: Entire program implements a cost calculator, not a guessing game. Missing all required components: no Random object, no loop, no comparison logic
